## Part 2 : Likert Scales

### Conceptual Review

-   **ACTIVITY & DISCUSSION :** apply the terms below to the [Satisfaction with Life Scale](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1207/s15327752jpa4901_13?casa_token=p4kB11wLsD0AAAAA:22OL81OAq3yFj1pcT3yRjsOjsPHQsg5G3A3-EgEKWjMmShXXBHV0J64j7BqJMUX8jfG2Lk2tdrUY)

![](images/clipboard-2712637950.png)
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Term**                  | **Definition**                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            | **Usage / Example** |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Scale**                 | The variable that you want to measure as a continuous variable.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Item(s)**               | The specific question(s) in the scale. Each item measures some aspect of the variable the researcher is interested in.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Response Scale**        | How people answer the scale items. People give a number rating on a fixed range of options with labels. Many 5-point scales include the following labels (1 = Strongly Disagree; 2 = Disagree; 3 = Neutral; 4 = Agree; 5 = Strongly Agree.)                                                                                                                                                               |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Positively-**           | An item that measures the high end of the scale, where answering “yes” to the question means you are high on this variable.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                               |                     |
|                           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                     |
| **Keyed Item**            |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Negatively-Keyed Item** | An item that measures the low end of the scale, where answering “yes” to the question means you are low on the variable.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
| **Reverse Scoring**       | How researchers “flip” the negatively-keyed items to be positively-keyed. To calculate how to reverse-score an item, you can add the lower and upper limit of the full range. So to reverse-score a response scale that goes from 0 to 4 = 0 + 4 = subtract the negatively keyed items from 4. A response scale that goes from 1 to 15 = 1 + 15 = subtract the negatively keyed items from 16. And so on. |                     |
|                           |                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                     |
|                           | This is confusing. We will practice in lecture some more, okay?                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                           |                     |
+---------------------------+-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------+---------------------+
:::

### In R : Personality Data

-   [Load the Dataset](https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/8wiolzigsmaw5luuhxsyz/AEvFVV2gYkvFeuAflXN39rY?rlkey=q16oosyqz6ognt9xdwl1oyoc5&dl=0). Check to make sure it loaded correctly. And go ahead and load the "psych" library too.

```{r}
library(psych)

d <- read.csv("~/Dropbox/!WHY STATS/Professor Datasets/Personality and Random Numbers/personality_random_number_data.csv", stringsAsFactors = T) # change your path here!

nrow(d)
head(d)
describe(d)
```

-   **Data cleaning :** zeroes are coded as missing data. this is not in the codebook, but I know this based on context and experience (*remember, there's a culture to statistics.*)

    -   I've worked with datasets from this source that use this convention (and do explain this feature in the codebook).

    -   there appears to be no missing data in the dataset; yet it is very unlikely that all participants answered all questions.

    -   the researchers measured personality with the Big Five, which is almost always measured on a 1-5 (or 1-7) scale, that allows for a "neutral" response.

```{r}
## REMOVING MISSING DATA : INDEXING APPROACH
### So we will need to remove the missing data. There are two ways to do this.

d == 0 # evaluates whether each entry in the dataframe is zero.

d[d == 0] # finds these zeros in the dataset.

d[d == 0] <- NA # replaces with zero

describe(d) # the variables now have some missing data, and the minimum values are not zero.

### ANOTHER WAY TO DO THIS IS WHEN LOADING THE DATA, YOU CAN SPECIFY WHAT NA.STRINGS SHOULD BE EQUAL TO.
d <- read.csv("~/Dropbox/!WHY STATS/Professor Datasets/Personality and Random Numbers/personality_random_number_data.csv",
              stringsAsFactors = T, 
              na.strings = "0") # r will look for 0 and replace with NA.
describe(d)
```

-   STEP 1: ORGANIZING THE ITEMS AND CHECKING THE ALPHA RELIABILITY

    ```{r}
    extra.df <- d[,22:31] # using the names and the codebook, these are the 10 extraversion items
    head(extra.df)

    alpha(extra.df) # r is warning me that some are negatively keyed...
    alpha(extra.df, check.keys = T) # seeing that some are negatively keyed...
    ## good to look at the codebook and confirm that these are negatively keyed (opposite of extraversion.)

    extraPOS <- extra.df[,c(1,3,5,7,9)] # defining the positively keyed items
    extraNEG <- extra.df[,c(2,4,6,8,10)] # defining the negatively keyed items
    range(extraNEG, na.rm = T) # a 1-5 scale...good! means I did my data cleaning correctly.

    extraNEG <- 6-extraNEG # reverse scoring my negatively keyed items

    extraCLEAN <- cbind(extraPOS, extraNEG)
    head(extraCLEAN)
    alpha(extraCLEAN) # high alpha; hooray.

    ```

-   STEP 2 : CREATING THE SCALE

    ```{r}
    d$EXTRA <- rowMeans(extra.df, na.rm = TRUE)
    hist(d$EXTRA) # What do y'all observe about the distribution of people's extraversion scores?
    ```

#### Method 1 : Find or Adapt an Existing Scale

-   **List of (Free) Scales :** <https://ipip.ori.org/newIndexofScaleLabels.htm>

-   **Google/Google Scholar :** add “construct” or “validation” or “scale” to your search

#### Method 2 : Write Your Own Scale from Scratch

-   Keep items phrased in the same way. ("I am someone who....")

-   Keep items on the same response scale (1-5 or 1-7); usually higher numbers indicate more agreement with the question.

-   Make sure to include positive and negatively-keyed items.
